display_asset.caption: The United Nations deputy high commissioner for human rights, Flavia Pansieri, center, has resigned.

summaries.body: A U.N. rights official who failed to take immediate action over allegations of child sex abuse by French soldiers in Central African Republic has resigned from her post.
Microsoft said that a new website would allow victims of "revenge porn" to report abuse, and that violating images and videos would be delisted from Bing search results.
Google released a feature that displays the locations you've been, at least those you've shared with Google.
LeBron James, the basketball star who made his feature film debut in "Trainwreck," is partnering with Warner Bros. in a deal covering television, film and digital projects.
A U.S. appeals court permanently blocked a North Dakota law that banned most abortions once a fetal heartbeat can be detected, as early as six weeks after conception.
Officials in Ohio are investigating how a confrontation with a University of Cincinnati police officer on Sunday led to the shooting death of an unarmed black man.
A U.N. rights official who admitted not following up for months on allegations of child sexual abuse by French soldiers in Central African Republic has resigned.
A Connecticut university professor said he tried to discourage his student from building a small drone that fires a handgun. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating.
Ikea is recalling about 27 million chests and dressers because they can tip over and crush children if they are not fixed to walls. Two children died after the MALM chests fell.
Apple shares fell, wiping out $38 billion in market value, after disappointing iPhone sales renewed concerns over whether it can keep making must-have products.
A man who flew a gyrocopter in restricted airspace before landing at the U.S. Capitol has rejected a plea deal that would have required him to spend 10 months in jail.
The British government announced plans to curb the costs of subsidies for renewable forms of energy like solar power, saying the industry could survive without support.
The minimum wage for employees at the University of California, the state's third-largest employer, will increase to $15 an hour by fall 2017, the university's president said.
A spokesman for Twitter said one of its teams showed poor taste when it organized a "frat party." The company is facing a gender discrimination lawsuit.
Sales of previously owned homes in the United States rose in June to their highest level in eight years, helped by low mortgage rates and job growth.
Four pilots said lasers were shone at their planes during flights over the New York City metropolitan area overnight, the Federal Aviation Administration announced.
The suicide bomber who killed at least 32 people at a cultural center in Turkey has been identified as a Turkish citizen believed to have had ties to ISIS, an official said.
Four fans of the Chelsea soccer team were barred from matches for five years for repeatedly pushing a black man away from their train as he tried to board.
A high-speed passenger train and a truck collided at a railway crossing in the Czech Republic, killing two people and injuring 12, the police said.
In a reversal, Hillary Rodham Clinton trails Jeb Bush, Marco Rubio and Scott Walker in the swing states of Colorado, Iowa and Virginia, a new Quinnipiac poll says.
More than 1,000 security officers, baggage handlers and wheelchair attendants at La Guardia and Kennedy Airports in New York voted to strike starting Wednesday night.
About 10,000 people were evacuated and three airports were closed after five volcanoes erupted in Indonesia.

posts.footer: NBC News | The New York Times

summaries.body: Allegations that a police video of the arrest of Sandra Bland, who was later found dead in a Texas cell, had been edited before its release will be investigated, an official said.
Myanmar's government and armed ethnic rebel groups resumed talks aimed at reaching a nationwide cease-fire agreement.

display_asset.credit: Jon Austria/The Daily Times, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Navajos voted to drop a requirement that their top leaders be fluent in Navajo. Supporters of the change said it would give young people more opportunities to seek office.
Fragments of the Quran in a British university library's collection are old enough to be the handiwork of a contemporary of the Prophet Muhammad, researchers found.
The president of Bolivia's soccer federation was jailed on charges that he misappropriated funds from a charity match.
As of Wednesday, Jason Rezaian of The Washington Post has spent a year imprisoned in Iran, by far the longest incarceration of a Western journalist since the 1979 revolution.

posts.footer: The South China Morning Post | The New York Times

summaries.body: China expects a record number of organ transplants to be carried out this year, despite a new ban on harvesting organs from executed prisoners, a health official said.

display_asset.caption: The courthouse in Dakar, Senegal, where a special tribunal is trying Hissène Habré, the former leader of Chad. The court said the trial would resume on Sept. 7.

summaries.body: The long-awaited trial of Hissène Habré, the former strongman of Chad, was suspended because he refused to speak and his defense team did not show up.
A jury will begin deliberating Wednesday in the case against State Senator Thomas W. Libous of New York, accused of using his influence to arrange a job for his son.
Marcus Mariota, the second pick in the N.F.L. draft and the last unsigned first-round draft pick, signed a deal with the Tennessee Titans.

display_asset.caption: Photographers raised their cameras in honor of Rodrigo Rojas during a 2003 ceremony in Santiago for victims of the Chilean dictatorship. Mr. Rojas was set on fire during a protest in 1986.

summaries.body: A judge in Chile ordered the arrest of two former army officers and five former noncommissioned officers accused in the 1986 burning death of a U.S. student.
A 24-year-old man was charged in Britain with plotting to run over an American serviceman and then kill him with a knife.
Security researchers said they discovered how to hack into cars remotely and control windshield wipers, radios, navigation and, in some cases, their brakes and steering.
Law enforcement authorities arrested four people in Israel and Florida and revealed a complex securities fraud scheme tied to the computer hack of JPMorgan Chase.
Quebec City and Las Vegas applied for National Hockey League expansion teams, the league announced. If approved, the teams would begin playing in 2017.

display_asset.caption: Karitiana children in their village near Porto Velho, Rondonia, Brazil. Scientists found that some people in the Brazilian Amazon have an ancient genetic tie to indigenous Australians, New Guineans and other Australasians.
display_asset.credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times

summaries.body: Some people in the Brazilian Amazon are very distant relations of indigenous Australians, New Guineans and other Australasians, two groups of scientists said.
Apple said services were restored to App Store, Apple Music and iTunes Store after a disruption of more than three hours.
Afghanistan banned the sale of toy guns that fire pellets after they caused injuries to more than 100 people during Eid al-Fitr. Above, children playing with plastic guns.
Citigroup was ordered to pay $700 million to customers and fined $70 million over illegal practices related to its marketing of credit card add-on products, regulators said.
In a tribute to the victims of the Chattanooga shooting, President Obama ordered that flags at federal buildings be flown at half-staff until July 25.

display_asset.caption: Robin Thicke and Miley Cyrus at the 2013 MTV Video Music Awards at Barclays Center.

summaries.body: Two years after Miley Cyrus’s controversial performance of “Blurred Lines” on MTV’s Video Music Awards, the singer will host this year’s ceremony in Los Angeles on Aug. 30.
Hundreds of firefighters battled to control a 700-acre wildfire that has been burning for a second day in central Washington State, closing an interstate highway.
Unemployment rates fell in 21 U.S. states in June and were unchanged in 17 others, the Labor Department said, as employers added jobs while the work force shrank.
President François Hollande of France promised steps to help farmers, who have been protesting over low prices. Above, a tourist walked to a site blockaded by farmers.
A Lufthansa plane with 108 passengers on board nearly collided with a commercial drone as it approached Warsaw's main airport on Monday, the airline said.
Women who develop slight but detectable deficits in memory and mental acuity late in life tend to decline faster than men with mild impairment, researchers said.
An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4 hit Fremont in the Bay Area of California early on Tuesday. There were no immediate reports of damage.
The European Court of Human Rights condemned Italy for failing to provide legal recognition to same-sex couples. Above, a pride parade in Turin last month.
Desmond Tutu, the former Anglican archbishop of Cape Town, was discharged after a week in a South African hospital where he was being treated for an infection.

posts.footer: The actress Emma Thompson, who says acting is more sexist and ageist today than it was in her youth, via Radio Times

summaries.body: I don’t think there’s any appreciable improvement and I think that for women, the question of how they are supposed to look is worse than it was even when I was young. So, no, I am not impressed at all.
FIFA, world soccer's governing body, said it would look into a report that minors from West Africa had been sent to Laos and forced to sign contracts with a club there.
In an annual defense paper, Japan accused China of "assertive" and "coercive" behavior, particularly in maritime disputes.
Planned Parenthood told Congress that abortion opponents had infiltrated its clinics for years and most likely have thousands of hours of footage they could "deceptively edit" and spread.
A spree of killings that has left at least 35 people dead in Brazil is raising suspicions that police officers may have organized a death squad in retaliation for a slain officer.
Garrison Keillor said he would step down as host of "A Prairie Home Companion," his long-running radio show, next year. The musician Chris Thile will succeed him.
Researchers who tracked comments made during sessions of the online game Halo 3 found that male players who harassed female ones were likelier to be bad at the game.
California water regulators proposed a record $1.5 million fine on a rural irrigation district accused of illegally diverting water in the midst of the state’s drought emergency.
President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria visited the White House ahead of President Obama’s coming trip to sub-Saharan Africa.

The snapping of a strip of metal holding a part in place appears to have doomed SpaceX, an unmanned cargo rocket headed to the International Space Station last month, a preliminary investigation has found.
President Obama said he would nominate Kathryn M. Dominguez, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan, to a seat on the Fed's Board of Governors.
Natural disasters, growing in intensity and frequency, forced more than 19 million people from their homes in 2014, an aid agency said. Above, the Philippines after a typhoon.
Liberia discharged its last four Ebola patients after they made full recoveries, leaving the country with no known cases of the deadly virus.

display_asset.caption: Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigning last week in Dover, N.H.
display_asset.credit: Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist for The New York Times

summaries.body: In a Facebook chat, Hillary Rodham Clinton jabbed Republican rivals, proclaimed her love of pantsuits and expanded on her plans for regulating Wall Street.
Philip II of Macedonia, the father of Alexander the Great, may be buried in a different tomb than was previously thought, according to a new study.
Alex Morgan, the U.S. women's soccer star, will appear on the cover of Fifa 16, the popular video game franchise. The game will feature women's teams for the first time.
Steven Michael Quezada, who played D.E.A. agent Steven Gomez in the television series "Breaking Bad," said he would run for county commissioner in Albuquerque.

posts.footer: Nick Denton, the founder of Gawker, after two editors resigned Monday over the deletion of the post.

summaries.body: I was ashamed to have my name and Gawker’s associated with a story on the private life of a closeted gay man who some felt had done nothing to warrant the attention.
Hundreds of farmers blocked roads in northern France demanding higher milk and meat prices. Above, a farmer sleeps in his tractor as part of the blockade near Caen.
Spain's Ruben Plaza Molina has won the 16th stage of the Tour de France by distancing a breakaway group in a final climb and holding them off downhill to the finish line.
Toshiba, the Japanese industrial giant, overstated its earnings by more than $1.2 billion over the last seven years, a committee of experts hired by the company said.
Heavy storms battered vast stretches of Poland, killing one person and injuring 17. Hundreds of homes were damaged, and thousands of people had no electricity.
Hackers leaked users' personal information from Ashley Madison, the infidelity website, to protest its claim that private information can be deleted from the site.
Lockheed Martin will buy Sikorsky Aircraft, maker of Black Hawk military helicopters, for $9 billion, bolstering Lockheed’s status as the world's biggest military contractor.
Morgan Stanley reported quarterly results that showed trading revenue and its wealth management business drove a 13 percent gain in net revenue.

posts.footer: Rachel Dolezal, the white woman who passed as black and resigned last month as head of the Spokane, Wash., N.A.A.C.P., in Vanity Fair

summaries.body: I’ve had my years of confusion and wondering who I really [was] and why and how do I live my life and make sense of it all, but I’m not confused about that any longer. I think the world might be — but I’m not.
An explosion at a cultural center in the Turkish town of Suruc, near Syria, killed at least 27 people and wounded 100, the Interior Ministry said.
The remains of Jewish gas chamber victims subjected to Nazi anatomy experiments have been traced to a medical research site in the French city of Strasbourg.
Four Italians working for a construction firm on Libya's west coast have been kidnapped, Italy's Foreign Ministry said.
FIFA's executive committee today will set a date to elect Sepp Blatter's successor and discuss a series of overhauls intended to ease pressure on the organization.
The Beijing police have detained at least four people on suspicion of uploading or distributing a video of a couple having sex in a Uniqlo changing room.
Adm. Scott Swift, the commander of the United States Pacific Fleet, confirmed that he joined a surveillance flight over the South China Sea over the weekend.
The International Champions Cup, founded to capitalize on top soccer clubs’ summer tours of the United States, is now pushing to add sponsorship and broadcast deals.
Stonemasons working for the United Nations have restored 14 mausoleums that were destroyed by Islamist extremists in the city of Timbuktu in northern Mali.
The AC/DC drummer Phil Rudd was released on bail after a weekend arrest in New Zealand. He was charged with breaching conditions of his home detention.
Mitsubishi Materials has become the first major Japanese company to apologize for using captured Americans for forced labor during World War II.
A months-long cyberattack on the U.C.L.A. hospital system put the personal information of as many as 4.5 million people at risk, officials said.
A Canadian man pleaded guilty to running an international boiler-room scheme in a case that stemmed from one of the largest penny stock investigations in U.S. history.
A judge refused to lower the $10 million bail for Marion Knight, the rap mogul known as Suge, after determining that a previously unseen video offered "nothing new."
At least 300 people were injured in a train crash during afternoon rush near Johannesburg, officials said. There were no immediate reports of fatalities or the cause.
Coca-Cola urged FIFA to undergo an immediate, independent reform process. The soft drinks company has sponsored the World Cup since 1978.

display_asset.caption: "Every now and then, I’ll reassess where I’m at in my career. I’m usually trying to think of what I’m going to do next," Eminem said.

summaries.body: In an interview, Eminem discussed his re-emergence this summer as the executive producer and lead artist on the soundtrack for “Southpaw,” a movie out next Friday.
SeaWorld suspended an employee after PETA accused him of trying to infiltrate the animal rights group and incite it to commit illegal acts.
A year after Eric Garner's death set off protests against the New York police, a photographer documented the lives of Mr. Garner’s family and black residents of Staten Island.
Anders Behring Breivik, who is serving a 21-year prison term for killing 77 people in an attack in Norway in 2011, has won a place to study at Oslo University from his cell.
The Vatican agreed to let a pediatric hospital nearby, in Rome, use Pope Francis' helipad around the clock for the emergency transport of patients and organs.
Dozens of residents fled their homes as wildfires burned around Athens, above; on rural land on the island of Evia near the Greek capital; and in the Peloponnese region.
The cost of living in the United States rose in June for the fifth consecutive month, as rents increased the most in almost two years, government statistics showed.

posts.footer: Europe1 Radio (in French) via Daily Motion

asset.embed_html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymotion.com%2Fembed%2Fvideo%2Fx2yaqv3&src_secure=1&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymotion.com%2Fvideo%2Fx2yaqv3&image=http%3A%2F%2Fs1.dmcdn.net%2FMSVc5%2Fx240-NxF.jpg&key=170aca4a25074a88942b11f27e7ca43f&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=dailymotion" width="480" height="269" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

summaries.body: Christine Lagarde, head of the International Monetary Fund, stepped up its campaign for Greek debt relief on Friday, saying interest should be cut and repayment extended.
